author: Michael Larabel
description: Fedora 43 had been planning for an early final target release date of 21 October. Unfortunately, that's not going to happen as a "No-Go" was declared at the Fedora Linux 43 release meeting...
title: Fedora 43 Is Not Ready For Release Next Week

author: Michael Larabel
description: Over the years we have seen various workarounds like disabling RDSEED for select AMD CPUs due to hardware bugs and early on in the Zen days were also some RdRand issues due to different problems. It turns out the newest AMD EPYC 5th Gen "Turin" processors have a new RDSEED issue...
title: Meta Uncovers RDSEED Architectural Issue In AMD EPYC Zen 5 CPUs

author: Michael Larabel
description: A Phoronix reader pointed out a bug report from 2015 now getting renewed interest... Linux software RAID via MD RAID, DRBD, LVM RAID, and similar software-based solutions can be broken from user-space around O_DIRECT usage. The issue is that these RAID arrays can be put silently into an inconsistent state across disks...
title: Linux Affected By Decade Old Bug In Software RAID Around O_DIRECT Usage

author: Michael Larabel
description: Posted to the Linux kernel mailing list and GNU Binutils mailing list today is an intriguing message from a longtime x86/x86_64 expert around a "a corporate entity other than Intel/AMD" using some x86 opcodes not used by AMD or Intel processors...
title: Mysterious Intrigue Around An x86 "Corporate Entity Other Than Intel/AMD"

author: Michael Larabel
description: With Linux 6.18 now past the merge window and many new features and changes introduced (https://www.phoronix.com/review/linux-618-features), I have begun testing out this kernel on various servers, desktops, and laptops at Phoronix. Linux 6.18 is quite important with expected to become this year's LTS kernel version upon its stable debut in December. Up today is a first look at Linux 6.17 vs. 6.18-rc1 performance using Intel Xeon 6 Granite Rapids server performance.
title: An Early Look At Linux 6.18 Performance With Intel Xeon 6 Granite Rapids

author: Michael Larabel
description: AOMP 22.0-1 was released on Wednesday as the newest routine update to this downstream of LLVM/Clang/Flang maintained by AMD that continues to carry their latest modifications for enhancing the C/C++/Fortran compiler offloading support to AMD Radeon/Instinct hardware using the likes of OpenMP and OpenACC...
title: AOMP 22.0-1 Brings Many Improvements For AMD's Fortran Compiler GPU Offloading

author: Michael Larabel
description: Merged today to LLVM Git for next spring's LLVM 22.0 release is support for the Intel Nova Lake ISA targeting with the "-march=novalake" option...
title: LLVM/Clang 22 Merges Support For Intel Nova Lake "-march=novalake"

author: Michael Larabel
description: Posted to the Linux networking mailing list on Wednesday were the latest patches for enabling the Homa transport protocol. Homa is the clean-sheet design aiming to become an alternative to TCP within data centers and capable of offering 10~100x reductions in tail latency for short messages...
title: Latest Linux Patches For Homa Posted: TCP Alternative With 10~100x Lower Tail Latency

author: Michael Larabel
description: Announced nearly one year ago was the OpenWrt One as a router/AP that is "hacker-friendly" and open-source. The OpenWrt One is powered by a Filogic 820 SoC and features WiFi 6. This official OpenWrt device is manufactured by Banana Pi. While there is downstream open-source code available for customizing the OpenWrt One to your heart's content, the upstream Linux kernel support to date hasn't been full-featured...
title: Proposed Patches Make Upstream Linux Kernel Usable For The OpenWrt One Router

author: Michael Larabel
description: SYCLBIN has been proposed by a longtime Intel compiler expert as a new way for storing SYCL device code for use as part of their GPU/XPU programming ambitions...
title: Intel Proposes "SYCLBIN" As New Format For SYCL Device Code

author: Michael Larabel
description: The latest Mesa Git code is now under version Mesa 26.0-devel with the Mesa 25.3 code being branched overnight for what will become this quarter's stable feature release...
title: Mesa 26.0 Enters Feature Development With Mesa 25.3 Branched
